comments.text:
+ivory griffin They believe that Simon Peter (Saint Peter) was the most 
prominent of the Twelve Apostles and that he had been hand picked by Jesus 
to lead the church, to be "...the rock I shall build my church on..." and 
hold the first place of honor and authority (as many other Christians also 
believe). In Catholicism however, this "Primacy of Peter" is said to extend 
in perpetuity to the Pope over other bishops throughout the Church via the 
doctrine of Apostolic succession (method whereby a series of bishops, each 
consecrated by other bishops who were consecrated similarly in a succession 
going back to Simon Peter and the original apostles). This extension of 
Petrine Primacy to one chosen bishop is known as the Primacy of the Roman 
Pontiff, also known as Primacy of the Bishop of Rome. This Catholic Church 
doctrine holds that the papacy has authority, delegated from Jesus, 
preserved by Apostolic succession, chosen through the assembly of bishops 
and guided by god, to rule over the entire Church.

At least that's the story...I think its rather interesting.

comments.text:
The liberal wing of the Church of England leadership is at least as vocal 
and powerful (the "power" involved mostly affecting the Church itself, as 
the Bishops in the House of Lords rarely seem to sway anything from where 
it was going anyway) as the conservative wing. In fact, I think they're 
more powerful and numerous, with at least the most recent two Archbishops 
of Canterbury being liberal. You get the feeling they'd be even more so if 
not trying to avoid a schism with the conservative Anglican Churches of 
other countries. This is the case with all European countries I know of 
with a state religion other than Roman Catholicism or the Eastern Orthodox 
Church. I don't know what ideas I'm hoping American progressive Christians 
can take from this - get a state-funded official Church to 
counter-intuitively reduce the greed & political influence of religion? 
LOL, can't see that happening - but it might be nice for you to know it's 
possible to make yourselves heard just as much, in theory.

comments.author: writerconsidered

comments.text:
+Richard Blackmore Please. While everyone has the "ability" to handle it, 
religious people are just better at it. I experience much more discomfort 
from it now than when I did when I was religious. Mostly because when I was 
religious I was sure I was right about my beliefs and anything that 
contradicted it was easily shrugged off, because surely it must be wrong or 
not completely correct.

Whereas now I have a lot more intellectual honesty and if something 
contradicts my preconceived notions, then I *have* to investigate which is 
more accurate, my preconceptions or the new information. I don't have the 
luxury of just assuming that I'm right like I once did.

As for the Pope's nonsense, I'm referring to his smokescreen that everyone 
seems to be buying into. When the man says that the church needs to focus 
less on certain social issues, all he's really saying is that he doesn't 
want those things to be as visible to the public, because he hasn't 
actually changed his position on gay marriage, abortion, etc he is just 
changing what the church fights publicly. Neither the official church 
positions nor his own positions on these subjects have changed.

That and when it comes to the poor. He talks a lot about it and even puts 
on a show, but it's not like he's actually doing anything more with the 
exorbitant wealth of the church. If that changes then so be it, but the 
church still has a LOT to answer for, like child abuse, their atrocious 
condom policy, etc, and a few pretty words and some nice photo ops aren't 
going to make it go away in my mind. No matter how enamored everyone else 
becomes with him.

It's all just a P.R. push to counteract the Catholic Church's falling 
numbers due to the public's progressive shift on these issues.
comments.author: Raziel Silver

comments.text:
Everyone has the ability to "deal" with cognitive dissonance. Everyone.

dissonance exists. But... what exactly is the "nonsense" the Pope is 
engaging in? Kinda sounds like your disdain button got hit and went on 
auto-pilot.

comments.text:
+duo1666 You misunderstood me. Yes revelation is one argument, from a 
religion method but not science or philosophy method. An argument of "God 
told me"is not valid in either. As you said one needs to prove it hence why 
philosophy and science have developed methods to do just that. Philosophy 
and/or science can help prove or refute a revelation claim. A revelation 
method can not prove or refute a claim in philosophy or science. For 
example if I claim there is life say on a planet in a local star system is 
a scientifically accurate and true statement but my sole source of data is 
a revelation. This is data is rejected in those fields as the data is in 
question to begin with. There is no method in revelation which provides an 
repeatable experiment in which one can confirm the revelation. Again this 
is why science and philosophy branched away from religion. Just as theology 
has developed within religion as a method of understanding revelation and 
it's application.

cheaper than me paying half for Aetna!  maybe youre talking about the 
people who couldn't get private plans because they had pre-existing

comments.text:
+Bryan Michaels I am Tiktaalic by the way, sometimes Google+ randomly 
switches my profile.
comments.author: Bryan Michaels

comments.text:
+deathByStupid "If a member of the clergy does something wrong or 
interprets the churches teaching against biblical scripture it's perfectly 
legitimate to criticise them (especially if there are released dogmatic 
laws disagreeing with them)."

Actually, this wouldn't really work. The Church pretty much holds itself up 
as the only thing even qualified to interpret scripture, or at the very 
least the highest authority on the matter.
comments.author: Bryan Michaels

comments.text:
+Julian Silva Openly criticising church dogma can be considered heresy, 
criticising clergy doesn't mean anything it's perfectly normal. If a member 
of the clergy does something wrong or interprets the churches teaching 
against biblical scripture it's perfectly legitimate to criticise them 
(especially if there are released dogmatic laws disagreeing with them). 

This whole conversation started with the pope, now obviously being the head 
of the church gives the pope some leeway in that he doesn't get the same 
level of scrutiny as a priest. 

But only official pronouncements by the pope are considered dogma (like 
papal bulls), not everything the pope says is dogma, that is why the church 
is very, very careful about what goes into official announcements because 
they have to scourer over it like a legal document to make sure it doesn't 
violate previous dogma or scriptures.

If the pope simply has an opinion like for example capitalism not being 
great, he is stating a non-dogmatic opinion as a leader, he is not making a 
religious decree. You are free to discuss this, you are free to even debate 
this. In much the same way as if the Pope said he thinks Chelsea will win 
the BPL, someone could disagree and say no it will be Arsenal. This type of 
debate is perfectly fine.
comments.author: deathByStupid

comments.text:
+antred11
 You technically don't stop being catholic, even if you disagree with the 
church . . . If you are baptised, communicated and confirmed, you're 
basically part of the church with no other way out of it, other than 
getting a not of excommunication from your local bishop . . . But, a 
religion is a religion, a nationality is a nationality.
comments.author: Julian Silva

comments.text:
The way I see it, as being brought up in a very uptight rural Catholic 
environment . . . You are not supposed to criticise the pope, the clergy, 
not even nuns or monks, or even someone aspiring to be part of the clergy, 
nor show public disagreeance with them whatsoever. Sure, most modern 
catholics are basically your typical modern, moderately liberal 
persons(often moreso than protestants). Criticising the clergy openly is a 
HERESY, which is a very grave sin. You won't get excommunicated, but 
basically you're going against your very own statement of being roman 
apostolic.
comments.author: Julian Silva
